9.title: Components: Stoxy Form
9.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
9.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

a.title: Components: Stoxy Form
a.headline: Attributes
a.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

c.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
c.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
c.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

d.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
d.headline: Attributes
d.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  id Identifier for the accessed iterable object

e.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
e.headline: Usage

g.title: Components: Stoxy String
g.headline: Components: Stoxy String
g.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

h.title: Components: Stoxy String
h.headline: Attributes
h.body: Name Attribute   default Default value of the string, if no value is set

i.title: Components: Stoxy String
i.headline: Usage
i.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >

s.body:

Stoxy utilized IndexedDB to persist state objects. There could be two reasons you would want to persist your state objects: 

Persisted state objects are peristed through page page reloads / sessions 
Persisted state objects can be removed from cache, and only fetched when needed

1b.title: Getting started: Core functionality
1b.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
1b.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

1c.title: Getting started: Core functionality
1c.headline: Persistance

1d.title: Getting started: Core functionality
1d.headline: Updates
1d.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

1e.title: Getting started: Core functionality
1e.headline: Reactivity
1e.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ; 
  

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

1j.title: Getting started: Installation
1j.headline: Getting started: Installation
1j.body:
Stoxy can be installed as single packages or as a collection of all Stoxy elements and the core. 
To install the whole Stoxy project in one go, you can do so with 
npm  install  @stoxy/stoxy
  

Alternatively the packages can be installed as standalone installations

1k.title: Getting started: Installation
1k.headline: Stoxy core
1k.body:
THe functionality and core functions of Stoxy 
npm  install  @stoxy/core

1q.title: Recipes: Persisting data
1q.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
1q.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

1r.title: Recipes: Persisting data
1r.headline: Memory management
1r.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.

3f.title: Getting started: Core functionality
3f.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
3f.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

3g.title: Getting started: Core functionality
3g.headline: Persistance

3h.title: Getting started: Core functionality
3h.headline: Updates
3h.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

3i.title: Getting started: Core functionality
3i.headline: Reactivity
3i.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ;

3r.title: Recipes: Persisting data
3r.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
3r.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

3s.title: Recipes: Persisting data
3s.headline: Memory management
3s.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.

4c.title: Components: Stoxy Form
4c.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
4c.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

4d.title: Components: Stoxy Form
4d.headline: Attributes
4d.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

4e.title: Components: Stoxy Form
4e.headline: Usage

4f.title: Components: Stoxy Object
4f.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
4f.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

4g.title: Components: Stoxy Object
4g.headline: Attributes
4g.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  prefix Prefix to access wanted state object properties. Makes it possible for Stoxy to recognize plain strings to replace.

4h.headline: Usage

4i.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
4i.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
4i.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

4j.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
4j.headline: Attributes
4j.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  id Identifier for the accessed iterable object

4k.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
4k.headline: Usage

4l.title: Components: Stoxy String
4l.headline: Components: Stoxy String
4l.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

4m.title: Components: Stoxy String
4m.headline: Attributes
4m.body: Name Attribute   default Default value of the string, if no value is set

4n.title: Components: Stoxy String
4n.headline: Usage
4n.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >

7t.title: Recipes: Persisting data
7t.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
7t.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

7u.title: Recipes: Persisting data
7u.headline: Memory management
7u.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.

8d.title: Components: Stoxy Form
8d.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
8d.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

8e.title: Components: Stoxy Form
8e.headline: Attributes
8e.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

8f.title: Components: Stoxy Form
8f.headline: Usage

8h.title: Components: Stoxy Object
8h.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
8h.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

8i.title: Components: Stoxy Object
8i.headline: Attributes
8i.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  prefix Prefix to access wanted state object properties. Makes it possible for Stoxy to recognize plain strings to replace.

8r.title: Components: Stoxy String
8r.headline: Components: Stoxy String
8r.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

8s.title: Components: Stoxy String
8s.headline: Attributes
8s.body: Name Attribute   default Default value of the string, if no value is set

8t.title: Components: Stoxy String
8t.headline: Usage
8t.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >

9i.title: Getting started: Core functionality
9i.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
9i.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

9j.title: Getting started: Core functionality
9j.headline: Persistance

9k.title: Getting started: Core functionality
9k.headline: Updates
9k.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

9l.title: Getting started: Core functionality
9l.headline: Reactivity
9l.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ; 
  

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

cg.title: Components: Stoxy Form
cg.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
cg.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

ch.title: Components: Stoxy Form
ch.headline: Attributes
ch.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

ci.title: Components: Stoxy Form
ci.headline: Usage

cj.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
cj.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
cj.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

ck.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
ck.headline: Attributes
ck.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  id Identifier for the accessed iterable object

cl.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
cl.headline: Usage

cm.title: Components: Stoxy Object
cm.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
cm.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

cn.title: Components: Stoxy Object
cn.headline: Attributes
cn.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  prefix Prefix to access wanted state object properties. Makes it possible for Stoxy to recognize plain strings to replace.

co.title: Components: Stoxy Object
co.headline: Usage

cp.title: Components: Stoxy String
cp.headline: Components: Stoxy String
cp.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

cq.title: Components: Stoxy String
cq.headline: Attributes
cq.body: Name Attribute   default Default value of the string, if no value is set

cr.title: Components: Stoxy String
cr.headline: Usage
cr.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >

dk.title: Getting started: Core functionality
dk.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
dk.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

dl.title: Getting started: Core functionality
dl.headline: Persistance

dm.title: Getting started: Core functionality
dm.headline: Updates
dm.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

dn.title: Getting started: Core functionality
dn.headline: Reactivity
dn.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ;

dw.title: Recipes: Persisting data
dw.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
dw.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

dx.title: Recipes: Persisting data
dx.headline: Memory management
dx.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

gi.title: Components: Stoxy Form
gi.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
gi.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

gj.title: Components: Stoxy Form
gj.headline: Attributes
gj.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

gk.title: Components: Stoxy Form
gk.headline: Usage

gl.title: Components: Stoxy Object
gl.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
gl.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

gm.headline: Attributes
gm.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  prefix Prefix to access wanted state object properties. Makes it possible for Stoxy to recognize plain strings to replace.

gn.headline: Usage

go.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
go.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
go.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

gp.headline: Attributes
gp.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  id Identifier for the accessed iterable object

gq.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat

gr.title: Components: Stoxy String
gr.headline: Components: Stoxy String
gr.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

gs.title: Components: Stoxy String
gs.headline: Attributes
gs.body: Name Attribute   default Default value of the string, if no value is set

gt.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as:

hm.title: Getting started: Core functionality
hm.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
hm.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

hn.title: Getting started: Core functionality
hn.headline: Persistance

ho.title: Getting started: Core functionality
ho.headline: Updates
ho.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

hp.title: Getting started: Core functionality
hp.headline: Reactivity
hp.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ; 
  

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

hy.title: Recipes: Persisting data
hy.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
hy.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

hz.title: Recipes: Persisting data
hz.headline: Memory management
hz.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

kk.title: Components: Stoxy Form
kk.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
kk.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

kl.title: Components: Stoxy Form
kl.headline: Attributes
kl.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

km.title: Components: Stoxy Form
km.headline: Usage

kn.title: Components: Stoxy Object
kn.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
kn.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

ko.title: Components: Stoxy Object
ko.headline: Attributes
ko.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  prefix Prefix to access wanted state object properties. Makes it possible for Stoxy to recognize plain strings to replace.

kp.title: Components: Stoxy Object
kp.headline: Usage

kq.title: Components: Stoxy String
kq.headline: Components: Stoxy String
kq.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

kr.title: Components: Stoxy String
kr.headline: Attributes
kr.body: Name Attribute   default Default value of the string, if no value is set

ks.title: Components: Stoxy String
ks.headline: Usage
ks.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >

kt.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
kt.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
kt.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

ku.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  id Identifier for the accessed iterable object

ln.title: Getting started: Core functionality
ln.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
ln.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

lo.title: Getting started: Core functionality
lo.headline: Persistance

lp.title: Getting started: Core functionality
lp.headline: Updates
lp.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

lq.title: Getting started: Core functionality
lq.headline: Reactivity
lq.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ;

Stoxy can be installed as single packages or as a collection of all Stoxy elements and the core.

Alternatively the packages can be installed as standalone installations

m0.title: Recipes: Persisting data
m0.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
m0.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

m1.title: Recipes: Persisting data
m1.headline: Memory management
m1.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits. 

  
    
  
    Caught a mistake or want to contribute to the documentation?
    Edit this page on GitHub!

of.headline: Zero Configuration
of.body: With plug and play implementation, you're up and running in just a single line of code.

og.title: Stoxy
og.headline: Extensive tooling
og.body: Stoxy ships with framework agnostic components to use with the state management system to achieve optimal results with your Web Application.

oh.title: Stoxy
oh.headline: Extendability
oh.body: Built with small and atomic functions, allowing you to extend the functionality with predicates and delegates.

oi.title: Stoxy
oi.headline: Offline-ready
oi.body: Stoxy can utilize the IndexedDB for storage, allowing you to create offline-first experiences without the hassle.

om.title: Components: Stoxy Form
om.headline: Components: Stoxy Form
om.body:
Stoxy Form is a web component used for handling Stoxy state without
having to write any javascript. 
On submit, the form persists the form's data to state with the given key attribute. 
If the url attribute is set, the form creates a HTTP request before saving the data to state.

on.title: Components: Stoxy Form
on.headline: Attributes
on.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  action Either add  or set  dependeing on wanted to add to a colleciton in state, or deplace the state  url In some cases you might want to send the form data to the backend. For these situations you can declare the url property. If set, sends a fetch request to given url on submit.  method If url is set, specifies the HTTP method used for the request. Defaults to GET  requireok If url is set, specifies if the HTTP request is required to return a OK status before committing the object to state.

oo.title: Components: Stoxy Form
oo.headline: Usage

op.title: Components: Stoxy Object
op.headline: Components: Stoxy Object
op.body:
Stoxy Object is a web component used for sections of content, where you want to
access multiple keys of a single state object. 
This can be useful for example when generating user profile pages. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Object also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

oq.title: Components: Stoxy Object
oq.headline: Attributes
oq.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  prefix Prefix to access wanted state object properties. Makes it possible for Stoxy to recognize plain strings to replace.

or.title: Components: Stoxy Object
or.headline: Usage

os.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
os.headline: Components: Stoxy Repeat
os.body:
Stoxy Repeat is a web component used for iterating state content onto the web page. 
The repeat component is useful for situations where the state object is iterable
and is desired to be displayed as e.g. a list 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy Repeat also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

ot.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
ot.headline: Attributes
ot.body: Name Attribute   key Key in string form. Used as the name of the state object  id Identifier for the accessed iterable object

ou.title: Components: Stoxy Repeat
ou.headline: Usage

ov.title: Components: Stoxy String
ov.headline: Components: Stoxy String
ov.body:
Stoxy String is a web component used for situtations, where you want to
display a single state object in the DOM, for example the current item count. 
As with all of Stoxy elements, Stoxy String also updates it's contents automatically
as the state changes. No action needed from the developer side.

ow.title: Components: Stoxy String
ow.headline: Attributes
ow.body: Name Attribute   default Default value of the string, if no value is set

ox.title: Components: Stoxy String
ox.headline: Usage
ox.body:
import  '@stoxy/stoxy-string' ; 
  
< p >  < stoxy-string >  itemcount</ stoxy-string >  </ p >  
  
Say the state object of itemcount  was 5 at the moment, we would have our DOM as: 
< p >  < stoxy-string >  5</ stoxy-string >  </ p >

pq.title: Getting started: Core functionality
pq.headline: Getting started: Core functionality
pq.body:
Stoxy is a dynamic state management system, which allows the developer to handle state across the whole
application without hassle. 
Stoxy utilizes the IndexedDB  to persist
data across page reloads and navigation. The usage of IDB also means that state persisted onto it is accessible
even when the user is offline.

pr.title: Getting started: Core functionality
pr.headline: Persistance

ps.title: Getting started: Core functionality
ps.headline: Updates
ps.body:
Stoxy elements are a perfect tool for creating reactive web experiences. When using Stoxy elements, the developer
doesn't need to worry about reacting to state changes. The elements handle their state and updates to said state
automatically, without any input from the developer. 
The updates are ran in a dynamic fashion, and only the content that has updated will be changed. 
With elements like Stoxy Repeat , the iterable stateobject are
compared to their old state, and sorted automatically to match the new order of the
state array. Only the items in the wrong order are moved around the DOM, and the ones that didn't change order
will be kept untouched.

pt.title: Getting started: Core functionality
pt.headline: Reactivity
pt.body:
On top of the reactivity provided by the Stoxy elements, the developer can also subscribe to the
state updates happening around their web application. 
The developer is able to set a callback function to be called with the new data set onto the state, as the
state updates. This allows for reactive programming patterns to be done by the developer even without using
Stoxy elements. 
import  { sub}  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

sub ( "shoppingcart" ,  ( )  =>  console . log ( "Shopping card updated" ) ) ;

pv.title: Getting started: Installation
pv.headline: Getting started: Installation
pv.body:
Stoxy can be installed as single packages or as a collection of all Stoxy elements and the core. 
To install the whole Stoxy project in one go, you can do so with 
npm  install  @stoxy/stoxy
  

Alternatively the packages can be installed as standalone installations

q2.title: Recipes: Persisting data
q2.headline: Recipes: Persisting data
q2.body:
Persisting data means that the state persists through page reloads and even
navigation outside of the page. 
There are plenty of situtations where you might want to persist data. One example
would be persisting API data that doesn't update often, or implementing a Stale-While-Revalidate 
state management system 
Persisting data to IndexedDB isn't on by default, and needs to be opted in on a per-key basis. 
After declaring the key with persistKey  all the state of that key is persisted into the IndexedDB. 
import  {  persistKey }  from  "@stoxy/core" ; 

persistKey ( "shoppingcart" ,  "userhistory" ) ;

q3.title: Recipes: Persisting data
q3.headline: Memory management
q3.body:
Persisting data onto the IndexedDB could also have a performance benefit. When persisting data, the Stoxy
system only keeps the latest 5 cache objects in memory cache, and let's the garbage collection handle older
state objects. 
This means that for an application using a large amount of state keys, it might be beneficial to persist the data
to enable the memory management benefits.
